elements.content: The lithium aryloxide [4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2OLi] forms solvated molecular Li2O2 ring dimers in both 1,4-dioxane and 1,3-dioxolane solutions, as determined by NMR spectroscopic and cryoscopic studies. In turn, the geometry of these aggregates controls the architectures of the resulting extended networks upon crystallization from these solvent systems. Specifically, the tetrasolvated dimers act as novel tetrahedral or trigonal nodes to produce the unprecedented 63,66 pillared bilayer polymer [{(ArOLi)2·(μ-diox)2}·{(ArOLi)2·(diox)·(μ-diox)1.5}]∞ (2) and the three-dimensional diamondoid framework [(ArOLi)2·(μ-dioxol)2]∞ (3). The structure of 2 is particularly noteworthy, being composed of two fused hexagonal sheets to form an interrupted diamondoid net.
elements.clean_text: The lithium aryloxide [4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2OLi] forms solvated molecular Li2O2 ring dimers in both 1,4-dioxane and 1,3-dioxolane solutions, as determined by NMR spectroscopic and cryoscopic studies. In turn, the geometry of these aggregates controls the architectures of the resulting extended networks upon crystallization from these solvent systems. Specifically, the tetrasolvated dimers act as novel tetrahedral or trigonal nodes to produce the unprecedented 63,66 pillared bilayer polymer [{(ArOLi)2⋅(μ-diox)2}⋅{(ArOLi)2⋅(diox)⋅(μ-diox)1.5}]∞ (2) and the three-dimensional diamondoid framework [(ArOLi)2⋅(μ-dioxol)2]∞ (3). The structure of 2 is particularly noteworthy, being composed of two fused hexagonal sheets to form an interrupted diamondoid net.

elements.content: The lithium aryloxide 4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2OLi forms molecular Li2O2 ring dimers in 1,4-dioxane or 1,3-dioxolane solutions. These aggregates act as trigonal or tetrahedral nodes upon crystallization from these solutions to assemble a novel hexagonal bilayer and a diamondoid network, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The lithium aryloxide 4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2OLi forms molecular Li2O2 ring dimers in 1,4-dioxane or 1,3-dioxolane solutions. These aggregates act as trigonal or tetrahedral nodes upon crystallization from these solutions to assemble a novel hexagonal bilayer and a diamondoid network, respectively.

elements.content: The modular approach toward the rational assembly of extended metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has been met with considerable success. This strategy has enabled the preparation of highly ordered materials that are finding uses in a growing number of important applications. An emerging paradigm in MOF crystal engineering is that a relatively small number of high-symmetry topologies dominate. Indeed, two of the most commonly encountered MOF architectures are two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal sheets and three-dimensional (3D) diamondoid lattices. These are examples of unitary networks constructed by the interconnection of a single type of node, i.e., trigonal or tetrahedral. Herein, we report the characterization of an intermediate missing link between these two ubiquitous topologies, a pillared metal−organic bilayer composed of two fused hexagonal nets. This is a rare example of a binary network constructed from both trigonal and tetrahedral nodes, and to our knowledge is an unprecedented topology for a MOF. Furthermore, the rational synthesis of a related diamondoid network is also disclosed.
elements.clean_text: The modular approach toward the rational assembly of extended metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been met with considerable success. This strategy has enabled the preparation of highly ordered materials that are finding uses in a growing number of important applications. An emerging paradigm in MOF crystal engineering is that a relatively small number of high-symmetry topologies dominate. Indeed, two of the most commonly encountered MOF architectures are two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal sheets and three-dimensional (3D) diamondoid lattices. These are examples of unitary networks constructed by the interconnection of a single type of node, i.e., trigonal or tetrahedral. Herein, we report the characterization of an intermediate missing link between these two ubiquitous topologies, a pillared metal-organic bilayer composed of two fused hexagonal nets. This is a rare example of a binary network constructed from both trigonal and tetrahedral nodes, and to our knowledge is an unprecedented topology for a MOF. Furthermore, the rational synthesis of a related diamondoid network is also disclosed.

elements.content: We recently reported that molecular cage aggregates of s-block metal complexes can successfully be utilized as secondary building units (SBUs) to direct network assembly. For example, tetrameric cubanes of specific lithium aryloxides, (ArOLi)4, may be designed such that each metal center has a single open site for coordination to a Lewis base. In turn, employment of a ditopic linker results in these aggregates acting as tetrahedral nodes to form diamondoid networks (Scheme a). Similarly, Na6O6 hexameric aggregates may be employed as octahedral nodes to construct cubic frameworks (Scheme b). The incorporation of highly polar elements such as lithium and magnesium into MOFs is attractive due to their potential as solid-state reagents and also for the preparation of low molecular weight materials for the storage of small molecules such as dihydrogen.
elements.clean_text: We recently reported that molecular cage aggregates of s-block metal complexes can successfully be utilized as secondary building units (SBUs) to direct network assembly. For example, tetrameric cubanes of specific lithium aryloxides, (ArOLi)4, may be designed such that each metal center has a single open site for coordination to a Lewis base. In turn, employment of a ditopic linker results in these aggregates acting as tetrahedral nodes to form diamondoid networks (Scheme a). Similarly, Na6O6 hexameric aggregates may be employed as octahedral nodes to construct cubic frameworks (Scheme b). The incorporation of highly polar elements such as lithium and magnesium into MOFs is attractive due to their potential as solid-state reagents and also for the preparation of low molecular weight materials for the storage of small molecules such as dihydrogen.

elements.content:
Relationship between Selected Metal Aggregates and Their Potential Nodal Geometries a

a  (a) Tetrasolvated tetrameric cubane, (b) hexasolvated prismatic hexamer, and (c) tetrasolvated ring dimer.
elements.clean_text: 1  Relationship between Selected Metal Aggregates and Their Potential Nodal Geometries a        a  (a) Tetrasolvated tetrameric cubane, (b) hexasolvated prismatic hexamer, and (c) tetrasolvated ring dimer.

elements.content: We were interested in expanding the scope of our work to alternative types of well-characterized s-block aggregates and targeted the preparation of tetrasolvated dimeric complexes of lithium aryloxides, [(ArOLi·D2)2], where D = monodentate Lewis base. These are appealing SBU candidates since they are readily accessible by suitable tuning of both the electronics and the substitution pattern of the aryloxide ligand. They are also smaller and lighter than the tetrameric cubanes. In additon, the tetrasolvated dimers differ from the previously employed aggregates as they possess two, rather than one, well-defined potential points of extension from each metal, i.e., two donor solvents per lithium (Scheme c). We reasoned that if all four coordination sites could be linked to neighboring aggregates that the dimeric SBUs would act as tetrahedral nodes and, in turn, build 3D diamondoid networks. A reasonable alternative is that the dimers could act as square planar nodes if the pairs of bridging ligands on each metal center extend along the same plane.
elements.clean_text: We were interested in expanding the scope of our work to alternative types of well-characterized s-block aggregates and targeted the preparation of tetrasolvated dimeric complexes of lithium aryloxides, [(ArOLi⋅D2)2], where D = monodentate Lewis base. These are appealing SBU candidates since they are readily accessible by suitable tuning of both the electronics and the substitution pattern of the aryloxide ligand. They are also smaller and lighter than the tetrameric cubanes. In additon, the tetrasolvated dimers differ from the previously employed aggregates as they possess two, rather than one, well-defined potential points of extension from each metal, i.e., two donor solvents per lithium (Scheme c). We reasoned that if all four coordination sites could be linked to neighboring aggregates that the dimeric SBUs would act as tetrahedral nodes and, in turn, build 3D diamondoid networks. A reasonable alternative is that the dimers could act as square planar nodes if the pairs of bridging ligands on each metal center extend along the same plane.

elements.content: To select suitable dimers for study, we prepared a series of lithium aryloxides by deprotonaton of the appropriate phenol with butyllithum. The complexes were then screened to determine their molecular aggregation behavior in both 1,4-dioxane and 1,3-dioxolane. These didentate solvent systems were chosen as they provide complementary properties for solution studies. In particular, dioxane is ideal for cryoscopic studies, whereas dioxolane is a convenient solvent for low-temperature NMR analyses, with melting points of 12 and −95 °C, respectively. In addition, both solvents have the potential to be employed as divergent linkers for the polymerization of the SBUs.
elements.clean_text: To select suitable dimers for study, we prepared a series of lithium aryloxides by deprotonaton of the appropriate phenol with butyllithum. The complexes were then screened to determine their molecular aggregation behavior in both 1,4-dioxane and 1,3-dioxolane. These didentate solvent systems were chosen as they provide complementary properties for solution studies. In particular, dioxane is ideal for cryoscopic studies, whereas dioxolane is a convenient solvent for low-temperature NMR analyses, with melting points of 12 and -95 °C, respectively. In addition, both solvents have the potential to be employed as divergent linkers for the polymerization of the SBUs.

elements.content: Jackman has previously demonstrated that the aggregation state of lithium aryloxides can be correlated with the difference (Δ) between the 13C chemical shift positions of the para-carbons of the complex and the corresponding anisole (where Δ values of approximately 4−6, 12−14, and 15−18 ppm correspond with the formation of tetramers, dimers, and monomers respectively). One of the promising salts identified from our study was lithium 4-bromo-2,6-dimethylphenoxide (1). Complex 1 displays single sets of 1H and 13C NMR signals in both dioxane and dioxolane solutions. Moreover, the 1H and 13C NMR signals within the dioxolane spectra shift by less than 0.1 and 1 ppm, respectively, over the temperature 20 to −80 °C. This behavior is indicative of a single major solution aggregate being present. Complex 1 also gave almost identical Δ values of 13.3 and 13.4 ppm in dioxane and dioxolane solutions (20 °C, 0.5 M), suggesting similar dimeric aggregation. Cryoscopic studies of 1 in dioxane supported the assignment of dimeric solution aggregation, with a calculated degree of association of 2.13 ± 0.09, over the concentration range 0.03−0.15 mol L-1.
elements.clean_text: Jackman has previously demonstrated that the aggregation state of lithium aryloxides can be correlated with the difference (Δ) between the 13C chemical shift positions of the para-carbons of the complex and the corresponding anisole (where Δ values of approximately 4-6, 12-14, and 15-18 ppm correspond with the formation of tetramers, dimers, and monomers respectively). One of the promising salts identified from our study was lithium 4-bromo-2,6-dimethylphenoxide (1). Complex 1 displays single sets of 1H and 13C NMR signals in both dioxane and dioxolane solutions. Moreover, the 1H and 13C NMR signals within the dioxolane spectra shift by less than 0.1 and 1 ppm, respectively, over the temperature 20 to -80 °C. This behavior is indicative of a single major solution aggregate being present. Complex 1 also gave almost identical Δ values of 13.3 and 13.4 ppm in dioxane and dioxolane solutions (20 °C, 0.5 M), suggesting similar dimeric aggregation. Cryoscopic studies of 1 in dioxane supported the assignment of dimeric solution aggregation, with a calculated degree of association of 2.13 ± 0.09, over the concentration range 0.03-0.15 mol L-1.

elements.content: With the molecular aggregation studies in hand, the polymerization of 1 was attempted in both neat dioxane and dioxolane solutions. These systems proved to be amenable to crystallization, and the structures of the polymers [{(ArOLi)2·(μ-diox)2}·{(ArOLi)2·(diox)·(μ-diox)1.5}]∞ 2 and [(ArOLi)2·(μ-dioxol)2]∞ 3 were subsequently elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, where Ar = 4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2, diox = 1,4-dioxane and dioxol = 1,3-dioxolane. Both complexes were reproducibly prepared as single phase species as determined by multiple unit cell checks of single crystals and also by analyses of the X-ray powder patterns of the bulk materials.
elements.clean_text: With the molecular aggregation studies in hand, the polymerization of 1 was attempted in both neat dioxane and dioxolane solutions. These systems proved to be amenable to crystallization, and the structures of the polymers [{(ArOLi)2⋅(μ-diox)2}⋅{(ArOLi)2⋅(diox)⋅(μ-diox)1.5}]∞ 2 and [(ArOLi)2⋅(μ-dioxol)2]∞ 3 were subsequently elucidated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, where Ar = 4-Br-2,6-Me2C6H2, diox = 1,4-dioxane and dioxol = 1,3-dioxolane. Both complexes were reproducibly prepared as single phase species as determined by multiple unit cell checks of single crystals and also by analyses of the X-ray powder patterns of the bulk materials.

elements.content: Figure shows a section of the extended framework of 2. The first point of note in 2 is the incorporation of the desired tetrasolvated Li2O2 dimeric rings as the basic building blocks of the structure. However, unexpectedly there are two distinct types of dimeric SBU present. One set of dimers is four-connected, with all four dioxanes bridging between neighboring aggregates, whereas the second set are three-connected, with only three bridging dioxanes and a single terminal dioxane. Hence, 2 is a binary MOF net composed of an equal distribution of tetrahedral and trigonal nodes.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows a section of the extended framework of 2. The first point of note in 2 is the incorporation of the desired tetrasolvated Li2O2 dimeric rings as the basic building blocks of the structure. However, unexpectedly there are two distinct types of dimeric SBU present. One set of dimers is four-connected, with all four dioxanes bridging between neighboring aggregates, whereas the second set are three-connected, with only three bridging dioxanes and a single terminal dioxane. Hence, 2 is a binary MOF net composed of an equal distribution of tetrahedral and trigonal nodes.

elements.content: Section of the bilayer2 viewed through the plane of the chair-shaped hexagonal nets. Dioxane pillars can be seen bridging between the two layers. Only oxygen centers of the aryloxides are shown, and all hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. Green = lithium, red = oxygen and gray = carbon.
elements.clean_text: 1  Section of the bilayer2 viewed through the plane of the chair-shaped hexagonal nets. Dioxane pillars can be seen bridging between the two layers. Only oxygen centers of the aryloxides are shown, and all hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. Green = lithium, red = oxygen and gray = carbon.

elements.content: The extended structure of 2 proved to be remarkable. Each trigonal node links to three tetrahedral nodes to form a 2D hexagonal sheet. In turn, the tetrahedral nodes link to three trigonal nodes within the layer but also connect to complementary tetrahedral nodes of a second sheet (Figure ). Overall, this results in the assembly of a unique bilayer structure. Figure highlights the use of dioxane molecules as pillars connecting the two hexagonal sheets. Additionally, the terminal dioxane molecules associated with the trigonal nodes can be clearly seen protruding above and below the bilayer. This topology can be described as an intermediate between the archetypal structures of the elemental allotropes black phosphorus and diamond. Using the Schläfli nomenclature, this topology is classified as a 63,66 net, where the three-connected node is surrounded by three six-membered rings, and the four-connected node is surrounded by six six-membered rings. Only a small number of (3/4)-connected binary MOFs have been characterized to date. These include derivatives of the 3D nets boracite, twisted boracite, Pt3O4, and cubic C3N4, and also an unusual 2D tiling of pentagons.
elements.clean_text: The extended structure of 2 proved to be remarkable. Each trigonal node links to three tetrahedral nodes to form a 2D hexagonal sheet. In turn, the tetrahedral nodes link to three trigonal nodes within the layer but also connect to complementary tetrahedral nodes of a second sheet (Figure ). Overall, this results in the assembly of a unique bilayer structure. Figure  highlights the use of dioxane molecules as pillars connecting the two hexagonal sheets. Additionally, the terminal dioxane molecules associated with the trigonal nodes can be clearly seen protruding above and below the bilayer. This topology can be described as an intermediate between the archetypal structures of the elemental allotropes black phosphorus and diamond. Using the Schläfli nomenclature, this topology is classified as a 63,66 net, where the three-connected node is surrounded by three six-membered rings, and the four-connected node is surrounded by six six-membered rings. Only a small number of (3/4)-connected binary MOFs have been characterized to date. These include derivatives of the 3D nets boracite, twisted boracite, Pt3O4, and cubic C3N4, and also an unusual 2D tiling of pentagons.

elements.content: Top:  a topolological representation of2 highlighting the connectivities of the tetrahedral (blue) and trigonal (green) nodes. The spheres are positioned at the centers of the Li2O2 rings. Bottom:  schematic view of the two types of dimeric SBUs present.

elements.content: Although a handful of MOF bilayers derived from pairs of 44 nets have been reported, we are unaware of any 63,66 MOF bilayers comparable to 2. The closest structural analogues to 2 are hydrogen-bonded bilayers. In particular, frameworks prepared through the combination of guanidinium cations (acting as trigonal nodes) and organodisulfonate anions (acting as the tetrahedral pillars) have been intensively studied due to their tunable host−guest chemistry.
elements.clean_text: Although a handful of MOF bilayers derived from pairs of 44 nets have been reported, we are unaware of any 63,66 MOF bilayers comparable to 2. The closest structural analogues to 2 are hydrogen-bonded bilayers. In particular, frameworks prepared through the combination of guanidinium cations (acting as trigonal nodes) and organodisulfonate anions (acting as the tetrahedral pillars) have been intensively studied due to their tunable host-guest chemistry.

elements.content: Structural analysis of complex 3 again revealed that the desired tetrasolvated Li2O2 ring dimers are retained upon crystallization. As in 2, the asymmetric unit of 3 indicated the presence of a pair of connected but crystallographically independent dimers; however, both now act as tetrahedral nodes. Overall, this results in the formation of a distorted 3D diamondioid lattice as was originally targeted (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Structural analysis of complex 3 again revealed that the desired tetrasolvated Li2O2 ring dimers are retained upon crystallization. As in 2, the asymmetric unit of 3 indicated the presence of a pair of connected but crystallographically independent dimers; however, both now act as tetrahedral nodes. Overall, this results in the formation of a distorted 3D diamondioid lattice as was originally targeted (Figure ).

elements.content: Section of the diamondoid structure of3 showing a view down the hexagonal “channels”. Only oxygen centers of the aryloxides are shown, and all hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. Green = lithium, red = oxygen, and gray = carbon.
elements.clean_text: 3  Section of the diamondoid structure of3 showing a view down the hexagonal "channels". Only oxygen centers of the aryloxides are shown, and all hydrogen atoms are removed for clarity. Green = lithium, red = oxygen, and gray = carbon.

elements.content: Rather surprisingly, only a handful of crystal structures containing dioxolane as Lewis base have been reported. Moroever, only two of these complexes, the lithium borohydrides [LiBH4·(dioxol)]∞ and [LiB(NMe2)H3·(dioxol)]∞, form coordination polymers (both adopt 2D nets). As evident from the structure of 3, the dioxolane molecules act as linear linkers similar to dioxane. Comparison of the metrical parameters in 2 and 3 reveals that both the localized and the framework geometries are similar. For example, the mean Li−OAr bond lengths are 1.895 and 1.896 Å in 2 and 3, respectively. However, the mean Li−O(donor) distances in 2 and 3 vary somewhat, being 2.009 and 2.073 Å, respectively. Also, dioxane is a slightly longer linker than dioxolane leading to greater mean separations between neighboring ring centroids, 7.982 and 7.589 Å in 2 and 3, respectively. Finally, the mean angles between these centroids are 109.2° in 2 and 108.8° in 3. Overall, these values demonstrate that dioxane and dioxolane possess comparable properties as didentate linkers.
elements.clean_text: Rather surprisingly, only a handful of crystal structures containing dioxolane as Lewis base have been reported. Moroever, only two of these complexes, the lithium borohydrides [LiBH4⋅(dioxol)]∞ and [LiB(NMe2)H3⋅(dioxol)]∞, form coordination polymers (both adopt 2D nets). As evident from the structure of 3, the dioxolane molecules act as linear linkers similar to dioxane. Comparison of the metrical parameters in 2 and 3 reveals that both the localized and the framework geometries are similar. For example, the mean Li-OAr bond lengths are 1.895 and 1.896 Å in 2 and 3, respectively. However, the mean Li-O(donor) distances in 2 and 3 vary somewhat, being 2.009 and 2.073 Å, respectively. Also, dioxane is a slightly longer linker than dioxolane leading to greater mean separations between neighboring ring centroids, 7.982 and 7.589 Å in 2 and 3, respectively. Finally, the mean angles between these centroids are 109.2° in 2 and 108.8° in 3. Overall, these values demonstrate that dioxane and dioxolane possess comparable properties as didentate linkers.

elements.content: Several coordination polymers composed of lithiated ring dimers have previously been characterized, although these have usually been prepared inadvertently rather than by design. These polymers fall into two main catagories:  1D polymeric chains19 and 2D square (4,4) sheets. Simple 1D chains are most commonly produced via bridging of the dimers by a bidenate base, as seen for [{(tBuCH2)PhNLi}2·(tmeda)]∞. The dimers can therefore be considered to be linear nodes in these species. The 2D square nets normally employ anions that contain a nonchelating Lewis base that links between neighboring dimers, as exemplified by [(RO)2P(O)CHC⋮NLi·(thf)]∞, where R = Et or iPr. In these instances, the dimers can be considered to be square-planar nodes. No examples of Li2X2 trigonal or tetrahedral nodes similar to those present within 2 and 3 have previously been reported, where X = any atom. Moreover, complex 3 is the first reported example of a 3D network of any type constructed from Li2X2 dimers.
elements.clean_text: Several coordination polymers composed of lithiated ring dimers have previously been characterized, although these have usually  been prepared inadvertently rather than by design. These polymers fall into two main catagories: 1D polymeric chains19 and 2D square (4,4) sheets. Simple 1D chains are most commonly produced via bridging of the dimers by a bidenate base, as seen for [{(tBuCH2)PhNLi}2⋅(tmeda)]∞. The dimers can therefore be considered to be linear nodes in these species. The 2D square nets normally employ anions that contain a nonchelating Lewis base that links between neighboring dimers, as exemplified by [(RO)2P(O)CHC⋮NLi⋅(thf)]∞, where R = Et or iPr. In these instances, the dimers can be considered to be square-planar nodes. No examples of Li2X2 trigonal or tetrahedral nodes similar to those present within 2 and 3 have previously been reported, where X = any atom. Moreover, complex 3 is the first reported example of a 3D network of any type constructed from Li2X2 dimers.

elements.content: The present work demonstrates that tetrasolvated Li2O2 dimers can be used as SBUs to construct coordination networks. Indeed, the assembly of the diamondoid network 3 was in accord with our initial predictions. The unprecedented bilayer 2 is essentially an interupted diamondoid lattice, and the formation of this new MOF topology illustrates that the use of s-block SBUs offer new possibilities in the area of network assembly. Finally, through further studies we hope to be able to rationalize the different topologies adopted by these closely related systems.
elements.clean_text: The present work demonstrates that tetrasolvated Li2O2 dimers can be used as SBUs to construct coordination networks. Indeed, the assembly of the diamondoid network 3 was in accord with our initial predictions. The unprecedented bilayer 2 is essentially an interupted diamondoid lattice, and the formation of this new MOF topology illustrates that the use of s-block SBUs offer new possibilities in the area of network assembly. Finally, through further studies we hope to be able to rationalize the different topologies adopted by these closely related systems.

elements.content: All synthetic procedures and subsequent characterization data for compounds 2 and 3; details of the solution aggregation studies using cryoscopy and NMR spectroscopy; crystal structure solutions and refinements of 2 and 3 in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Assembly of 63,66-Pillared Metal−Organic Bilayers and Diamondoid Lattices
Using Molecular Li2O2 Ring Dimers as Secondary Building Units
